Who do you agree with?

Tom and Katie are discussing bar models. Tom says this bar model represents \( 5 x \) \begin{tabular}{l|l}
\hline \( 5 \) & \( x \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Katie says this bar model represents \( 5 x \) \begin{tabular}{l|l|l|l|l|}
\( x \) & \( x \) & \( x \) & \( x \) & \( x \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Who do you agree with?

ConstructName: Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons

\(
y=x^{2}-1
\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}

\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?

ConstructName: Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1
QuestionText:
Mo wants to solve this equation using the quadratic formula.
\(
5 h^{2}-3 h-2=0
\)

What total should replace the square? \( \begin{array}{l} \frac{ ?\pm \sqrt{9-(-40)}}{?} \\ = \frac{ ?\pm \sqrt{\square}}{?} \end{array} \)

ConstructName: Interpret and carry out mental division using a bar model
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing this bar model ![A comparison bar model showing 188 is the same as four lots of 47]() Tom uses the bar model to write:
\[
188 \div 4=47
\] Katie uses the bar model to write:
\[
188 \div 47=4
\] Who do you agree with?

\]

Paul does: \( (15+2) \times 3-4 \)

Pattern 3 is 11 squares: they are arranged as a rectangle, 3 squares high and 3 squares wide and then 2 more squares, 1 each side of the middle squares (vertically). Pattern 4 is 14 squares arranged as a rectangle, 3 squares high and 4 squares wide and then 2 more squares, 1 each side of the middle squares.]()

Jo and Paul are discussing mental addition and subtraction strategies.

Jo says a good way to add \( 19 \) is to add \( 10 \), then another \( 10 \) and then subtract \( 1 \).

Paul says a good way to subtract \( 19 \) is to subtract \( 10 \), then another \( 10 \) and then add \( 1 \).

Who is correct?

ConstructName: Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
QuestionText:
![A grid of 7 squares across and 7 squares up. A red vertical line goes from the bottom to the top of the grid, it is 4 squares left from the edge of the grid. An orange rectangle (3 squares width and 2 squares height) is drawn to the left of the red line, with its right-hand side on the red line.  The bottom side of the rectangle is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid. The top right corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter P, which is 5 squares up from the bottom of the grid on the red line. The bottom right corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter Q, which is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid on the red line. ]() Tom and Katie are discussing reflections

Katie says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( Q \) stays in the same position

AnswerBText: ![A four quadrant plane. Y axis --3 to 6 and x axis -4 to 7. A blue line goes from bottom left to top right sloping upwards. It goes through (-3, 0) and (0, 3). A red line goes from top left to bottom right sloping downwards. It goes through (0, 6) and (4, 0) ]()
AnswerCText: ![A four quadrant plane. Y axis --2 to 7 and x axis -4 to 7. A blue line goes from top left to bottom right sloping downwards. It goes through (0, 6) and (6, 0). A red line goes from top left to bottom right sloping downwards. It goes through (0, 6) and (4, 0) ]()

ConstructName: Recognise and use efficient methods for mental division
QuestionText: This is how Teddy calculates the answer to \( 600 \div 25 \) mentally "There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in 100. I then multiplied \( 4 \) by \( 6 \) to get \( 24 \). So \( 600 \) divided by \( 25 \) is \( 24 \)" Teddy uses the same method to calculate \( 800 \div 25 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this?
AnswerAText:
There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \) 
Then I multiplied \( 4 \) by \( 8 \) 
So the answer is \( 32 \)
AnswerBText:
There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \) 
Then I multiplied \( 8 \) by \( 6 \) 
So the answer is \( 48 \)
AnswerCText:
There are \( 6 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \) 
Then I multiplied \( 6 \) by \( 4 \) 
So the answer is \( 24 \)
AnswerDText:
There are \( 8 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \)
Then I multiplied \( 8 \) by \( 6 \) 
So the answer is \( 48 \)

ConstructName: Construct a triangle using Angle-Side-Angle
QuestionText: Which of the following best describes how to construct a triangle with side length \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) with angles of \( 40^{\degree} \) and \( 50^{\degree} \) either side?
AnswerAText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw a line \( 50 \mathrm{~cm} \) long that starts at the same end of the line and goes through the dot.
- Join up the end of this line with the other end of the \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) line.
AnswerBText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Set the compass width to \( 40 \mathrm{~cm} \) and draw an arc from one end of the line
- Set the compass width to \( 50 \mathrm{~cm} \) and draw an arc from the other end of the line
- Join up the ends of the line to the intersection of the arcs with straight lines
AnswerCText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the same end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle
AnswerDText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the other end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle

ConstructName: Given a situation sketch an appropriate displacement-time graph
QuestionText: John walks from home at a constant speed to a bench, stops for a rest, and then runs home at a constant speed. Which of the following displacement \( (d) \) time \( (t) \) graphs is most likely to illustrate John's journey?
AnswerAText:
![The graph has three sections.
The first section is a horizontal line, then a sloped line with negative gradient. The last section is a horizontal line.]()
AnswerBText:
![The graph has three sections.
The first section starts at (0, 0) and is a sloped line with steep, positive, uphill gradient, then a horizontal line. The third section is a sloped line with gentle, negative gradient that ends when it touches the horizontal axis.]()
AnswerCText:
![The graph has three sections.
The first section starts at (0, 0) and is a sloped line with positive, uphill gradient, then a horizontal line. The third section is another sloped line with a steeper positive gradient.]()
AnswerDText:
![The graph has three sections.
The first section starts at (0, 0) and is a sloped line with gentle, positive, uphill gradient, then a horizontal line. The third section is a sloped line with very steep negative gradient that ends when it touches the horizontal axis.]()

ConstructName: Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing this sequence. ![3 consecutive patterns of a sequence are shown. The first pattern is a green triangle inside a square shape that is made from 4 separate red sticks. The second term is Pattern 1 but with 1 more green triangle and 3 more red sticks so that the 2 triangles are enclosed by squares made from red sticks. The third term is Pattern 2 but with 1 more green triangle and 3 more red sticks so that the 3 triangles are enclosed by squares made from red sticks.]() Tom says the number of triangles in the \( 6^{\text {th }} \) term will be 
double the number of triangles in the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term.

Katie says the number of sticks in the \( 6^{\text {th }} \) term will be 
double the number of sticks in the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term.

Who do you agree with?

The bar chart shows the number of students in each year group who study French, Spanish and Chinese.

How many more Year \( 7 s \) than Year 8s study Chinese? ![An image of a bar chart with bars striped red and white for French, blue for Spanish and white for Chinese. The x-axis is marked 'year group' with options 7-11, and the y-axis is marked 'number of children'. ]()

ConstructName: Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a negative integer
SubjectName: Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x
QuestionText:
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -5 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?

ConstructName: Write the next term of a descending decimal linear sequence
QuestionText:
\( \begin{array}{llll}7.5, & 6.6, & 5.7, & ?\end{array} \)

What is the next term in this linear sequence?

ConstructName: Round the elements of a calculation to one significant figure to perform an estimation
QuestionText:
Estimate the value of
\(
\frac{4.12 \times 18.3}{0.226}
\)

ConstructName: Identify a transversal
QuestionText: What is the name given to the red line that intersects the two dashed lines? ![Shows two straight horizontal dashed lines that are converging and are both intersected by a solid red line]()

ConstructName: Convert between m³ and cm³
QuestionText:
\(
1 m^3 =\bigstar cm^3
\)

What should replace the star?

ConstructName: Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle
QuestionText: An isosceles triangle must have ...
AnswerDText: two sides of equal length and two equal angles.

ConstructName: Determine the function of a single function machine used to create an algebraic expression
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing this function machine ![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left has "input" written above it and "m" written inside it. The middle rectangle is empty and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "4m" written inside it.]() Tom says the function could be \( +3 m \)

Katie says the function could be \( \times 4 \)

Who do you agree with?

ConstructName: Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph
QuestionText:
\( £ 1 \) is \( 1.5 \) US dollars.
Which of these graphs shows the value of up to \( £ 10 \) in US dollars?
AnswerAText: ![A straight line graph from the origin. Y axis labelled US dollars extending to 10, x axis labelled pounds extending to 15]()
AnswerBText: ![A straight horizontal line graph from 15 on the y axis. Y axis labelled US dollars extending to 15, x axis labelled pounds extending to 10]()
AnswerCText: ![A straight line graph from the origin. Y axis labelled US dollars extending to 15, x axis labelled pounds extending to 10]()
AnswerDText: ![A straight line graph from approx 5 on the y axis. Y axis labelled US dollars extending to 15, x axis labelled pounds extending to 10]()

ConstructName: Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram
QuestionText:
There are \( 4 \) red balls and \( 3 \) yellow balls in a cup ![A cup with 4 red and 3 yellow balls in it. The balls are all the same size.]() Kate picks out two balls at the same time.

What is the probability at least one ball is red?

ConstructName: Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers
QuestionText: What answer would your calculator give if you typed in \(-5^{2}\) ![A scientific calculator]()

ConstructName: Calculate the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph
QuestionText:
The cost of a taxi-ride is shown on the graph.

What is the cost per mile? ![The graph is Cost (£) on the vertical axis and Distance (miles) on the horizontal axis. The graph is a straight line from (0, 2) to (5, 6)]()

ConstructName: For a given input find the output of a function machine
QuestionText:
Cally wants to use the function machine below to solve this problem:

I think of a number, double it, subtract 5, and the answer is \( 23 \).

Which of the following should replace the star? ![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and has "input" written above it. The next 2 rectangles are empty and the final rectangle on the right has a purple star inside it and has "output" written above it.]()

ConstructName: Use inequality notation to order fractions whose denominators are not multiples of the same number
QuestionText:
What sign would make this statement true?
\(
\frac{4}{6} ? \frac{10}{15}
\)

ConstructName: Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator
QuestionText:
Simplify the following, if possible
\(
\frac{5 m-10}{m^{2}+3 m-10}
\)

ConstructName: Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer
QuestionText:
Calculate:
\(
\frac{2}{5} \div 2
\)

ConstructName: Sketch curves in the form (x + a)(x + b) indicating where they cross the axes
QuestionText: \( y=(x-8)(x-6) \) \( y=(x-8)(x-6) \) Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis? Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis?

ConstructName: Given a description of an ascending sequence using quadratics in words, write some terms of that sequence
QuestionText:
A sequence is formed using the rule

Square the position and add \( 5 \)

What is the third term in the sequence?

ConstructName: Calculate distance where speed and time are in the appropriate units
QuestionText:
This displacement-time graph shows \( 10 \) seconds of Mo's journey home.

During that time he travelled at a speed of \( 15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).

What distance should replace the star? ![The graph has its vertical axis labelled Distance (m) and it has no scale written except for a star three squares up.
The horizontal axis is labelled Time (secs) and has the scale 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 in even steps.
The graph is a straight line sloping down from (0, star) to (10, 0).
]()

ConstructName: Solve problems involving converting between fractions, decimals and percentages
Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention
QuestionText:
Simplify, if possible:
\(
a \times 4
\)

ConstructName: Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed
QuestionText: The formula for the area of a triangle, \( A \), is ![Triangle with base labelled b and perpendicular height labelled h]() \( A=\frac{1}{2}(b \times h) \) Rearrange this to make the base, \( b \), the subject.

ConstructName: Convert between l and  cm³
QuestionText:
Complete this statement:
\( 4 \) litres \( = \)_________ \( \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)

ConstructName: Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving negative integers
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(1-4 v=3-9 v\)

Tom says you can write: \( 1+5 v=3 \)

Katie says you can write: \( -4 v=2-9 v \)

Who is correct?

ConstructName: Round integers to the nearest 10
SubjectName: Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)
QuestionText: What is \( 326 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 \) ?

ConstructName: Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units
QuestionText: Paige, Kaci and David want to find the area of the school playground. They each do it a different way. Who is correct? ![A compound shape made up of two rectangles.  Dimensions are 6 metres by 12 metres and also 4 metres by 8 metres. Two sides do not have measurements so need to be deduced]()

ConstructName: Carry out division  problems involving one negative integer
Describe an enlargement, with no centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1
SubjectName: Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes
QuestionText:
Shape \( Q \) is an enlargement of shape \( P \).
What calculation works out the constant of proportionality from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \) ? ![To similar star shapes labelled P and Q. They have the same side labelled for P it is 3cm and for Q it is 11cm]()

ConstructName: Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division
QuestionText:
What does the following equal?
\[
8-7+10 \times 3
\]

ConstructName: Distinguish between congruency and similarity
QuestionText: Tom and Katie are discussing congruence and similarity. Who is correct? Tom says these two squares are congruent ![An image of two squares. A little one and a big one. They are enlargements of each other.]() Katie says these two squares are similar ![An image of two squares. A little one and a big one. They are enlargements of each other.]()

ConstructName: Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object
QuestionText:
Jo and Paul are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Jo says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) anticlockwise"

Paul says: "a rotation of \( +270^{\degree} \) about \( (-1,1)^{\prime \prime} \)

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two trapeziums drawn on it and a centre of rotation marked on, one space to the right and one space up from the origin. Trapezium P has the coordinates: (-4,4) (-2,4) (-2,3) and (-4,1). Trapezium Q has the coordinates: (-4,-2) (-4,0) (-3,0) and (-1,-2).]()
